sense.name: sudden increase
sense.commentary: JUMP[+event] A sudden and decisive increase in something.
sense.examples: Intelli-Soft experienced a sales jump three years ago. There was a jump in attendance. As we can see, the graph shows a sharp jump near the y-axis.

sense.name: abrupt transition
sense.commentary: JUMP[+event] A kind of metaphoric leap between two things.
sense.examples: He made a successful jump from college to the majors. After the opening scene, the film makes a jump to the meeting of the two main characters. The Millennium Falcon made a jump into hyperspace.

sense.name: startled movement
sense.commentary: JUMP[+event] Refers to a sudden, involuntary movement. Usually made when afraid. Does not imply a leap into the air.
sense.examples: He awoke from his nightmare with a jump.

sense.name: parachuting
sense.commentary: JUMP[+event] A slangy way to refer to the act of descending with a parachute.
sense.examples: I've made forty-three parachute jumps into enemy territory.

sense.name: leaping upwards
sense.commentary: JUMP[+event] The act of propelling one's body into the air.
sense.examples: His jump over the hedge was truly spectacular. I won the high-jump competition after six months of training. As John grows stronger, his jumps are getting higher and higher!

sense.name: starting a car
sense.commentary: JUMP[+event] The act of starting one car using the power from another. Involves jumper cables.
sense.examples: I battery had died, so I asked Johnny to give me a jump.

sense.name: surprise
sense.commentary: Used to indicate that someone has caught a person in a state of unreadiness, or has taken a head start.
sense.examples: Boy, you really got the jump on me.
